content:
When I first saw the advertisements for the F1 movie I knew I had to watch it. I personally am not too into the sport, but the immersive visuals hooked me. At the start, you are introduced to Sonny Hayes, a man whose career almost ended in a brutal crash. Throughout the entire movie, this crash seems to be haunting him, even being the reason as to why he left the sport in the first place. He’s portrayed by Brad Pitt, who I know mostly for his roles as David Mills on Se7en and Tyler Durden on Fight Club. A couple months before I saw the F1 movie, I saw Se7en so I already had high expectations for the F1 movie. Anyway, he goes on to win the 24 Hours of Daytona and meets with his former teammate and close friend, Ruben Cervantes. His friend recruits him into his currently failing team known as APXGP, where he meets Joshua Pearce, a young rising star in the F1 scene. Pearce is played by Damson Idris, a person widely known for their role as Franklin Saint on Snowfall. Throughout the entire story, these two are our main characters. 
	Sonny Hayes' whole role in the entire movie is to be a mentor for Pearce. And that’s exactly what he does. One thing that I loved about Sonny was his calmness compared to Joshua. While Joshua is kind of like a hot head, Hayes keeps his cool in almost every situation. They are essentially the opposites of each other. Also, the evolution of their relationship is something that I thought was great. They begin with having a sort of rivalry and high egos; though, most of this is just Joshua. Thus, as the story progresses more, Joshua starts to kind of understand Hayes and they both create a mutual respect for each other and think of the team first rather than their own selves. In the end, one of the main points of the movie is their bond and how it grows.
	Moving on from the characters, the movie’s visuals are stunning. The movie shows the competitiveness within F1 and helps viewers understand what truly happens on the track. One thing I was surprised to find out about this was that some scenes were actually shot during the Grand-Prix’s. Also, the movie shows realistic racing, but this was something I expected since Lewis Hamilton was one of the producers of the movie. In my opinion, this is something that fits both casual movie watchers, and fans of F1. 
In conclusion, I think this is something that is worth watching. The characters are great, and so are the visuals. I can’t say much except to just tell you to watch it. It’s a great movie which can leave you with an interest in F1. There are many great things about this movie that I didn’t mention like the importance of Haye’s deck of cards. It’s a movie that will have you wondering about the next adventure of Hayes.

content:
Not being a particular Formula 1 fan, I didn't focus on the aesthetic boldness of director Joseph Kosinski. So I set aside any comparisons with the harsh realities of this world.
And I'm glad I did, because I loved this blockbuster. Admittedly, the storyline is somewhat farcical, with the sixty-year-old man called in to save a team in total decline. It's a bit like Jackie Stewart, having become a team manager, calling Jacky Ickx back in 2000 to do battle with Schumacher and Häkkinen.
But it's cinema, so it doesn't matter, right? Especially since the racing scenes are impressive. I didn't notice the time passing, and the film still lasts 2 hours and 35 minutes. And then there's the music by Hans Zimmer, of course.
I honestly had a good laugh. Javier Bardem is exquisite as usual, Damson Idris has a beautiful smile, little Kerry Condon is delicious as can be and Brad Pitt is still as cool as ever... "Who said anything about safe ?" 😉

content:
This movie really benefits from the fact it succeeds in its primary job as a movie, which is to entertain. I’ve seen so many movies that try to do so much with the plot that it gets in the way of being something to enjoy. F1 uses a generic plot because the plot is actually a platform to deliver some of the best cinematography and sound design work I’ve ever seen in a movie this year.

As an F1 fan, seeing this movie take place in actual race venues with genuine F1 fans (since they followed the F1 calendar to film during Grand Prix events) made the movie’s setting feel much more genuine even though the story is obviously fictional. The race sequences were amazing, with the actors driving alongside actual F1 racing drivers in their cars.

I think much of the criticism comes from a vocal minority of F1 fans and pundits who believe F1 is “above being portrayed by Hollywood,” which I think is quite ironic given that F1 is quite literally seen as a circus by those who exist outside of that bubble.

I actually think F1 could be a legitimate Oscar contender for some of the technical categories, and even best original song. We’ll have to see, but in general I agree that this was a true summer blockbuster.

content:
I watched it 2 times. The first time was about me looking for a fun action movie. The second time, was about me doing a team-building activity. I treated my research staff to this movie because I wanted them to understand the value of working as a team.

While the drivers are the ones front and center, the movie shows how it actually takes an entire team to win the races. No role is too small or insignificant. From the team owner singing the checks, to the drivers, the Engineer, Mechanics, Coaches, Analysts behind a keyboard, even to that person who is supposed to properly unscrew a tire had an indispensable role. I love how the movie showed just that. 

Everybody in the team was short of something. The lead driver was talented but was an ego-maniac. The older driver is experienced, but is physically and psychologically scarred. The team owner is losing money, the engineer is inexperienced, the mechanics lack confidence under pressure, but when they all come together they manage to nullify each others weaknesses. 

We now also adopt the mantra "Slow is smooth, and smooth is fast",

content: I really enjoyed this modern take on the old westerns where a mysterious gunslinger rides into town and is called upon to save the day, passing along their wisdom and maybe learning a little themselves, then ride off alone into the sunset after emerging victorious. Apart from the absence of all the political baggage and rejection of previous generations that has become the norm for the last however many years, it also subverts expectations in a good way for once by avoiding a few tropes that, while not bad necessarily, have been done in a slew of other movies. There's the scene, for example, where JP's friend and manager wants him to go out partying and networking again but JP has matured and realized that it's time to end that part of his life and tells his friend so in coded language. His friend pauses for a few beats and you wonder if this will be another 'sometimes those around you can't grow with you' moment before he surprises by accepting the change without drama. It's a nice moment that acknowledges that sometimes our better angels can win out, as is the case with Ruben who you might expect (rich guy fighting a cut throat political battle with reputation and millions of dollars on the line) would selfishly put his need for a win ahead of Sonny's health but instead shows that his concern and love for his friend is genuine and more important to him than winning or money. The story comes together nicely with plenty of exciting action and twists that keep you on your toes and ends on a positive note that feels true to the characters as they've been portrayed. It's not the greatest movie ever made, but it's fun and well constructed, has heart and, I think, holds up to repeat viewings which has been pretty rare of late.

content: Knock NASCAR all you want, Scotsman, but first of all it follows the format of the Roman chariot race -Ben Hur with blades around an oval, death to the competitors in front of thousands of screaming fans. It's the restart rule that puts the cars together to force wheel to wheel racing which you never ever get in F1. When Juan Pablo Montoya drove in NASCAR, he said it was the most challenging series he's driven in. He was not wrong. Having dozens of other cars only inches or feet away at nearly 200mph is a major challenge for any driver. See, F1 focused on the ultimate car, NASCAR focused on the ultimate race. We want to watch the dogfight play out, not watch cars which could be qualifying or maybe racing and who can tell the difference anyway zooming along once every few minutes with no idea who is in front if we didn't have a leaderboard. NASCAR is a gladiatorial spectacle. Or at least it used to be before it became tamed and PC and tried to cater to "modern audiences" in it's own way. The other beautiful thing about it was that back in the day, a middle class small business owner could field a team. Cars were not that expensive, and they weren't that complex. It was a blue collar sport for working class people. Surely you can appreciate that.
